name: Sir Michael Francis Atiyah
motivation: Did joint work with Hirzebruch in K-theory; proved jointly with Singer the index theorem of elliptic operators on complex manifolds; worked in collaboration with Bott to prove a fixed point theorem related to the "Lefschetz formula".

name: Lennart Carleson
motivation: For his profound and seminal contributions to harmonic analysis and the theory of smooth dynamical systems.

name: Pierre Deligne
motivation: For providing a solution of the three Weil conjectures concerning generalizations of the Riemann hypothesis to finite fields. His work did much to unify algebraic geometry and algebraic number theory.

name: Hillel Furstenberg
motivation: Together with Gregory Margulis for pioneering the use of methods from probability and dynamics in group theory, number theory and combinatorics.

name: Mikhail Leonidovich Gromov
motivation: For his revolutionary contributions to geometry.

name: Robert P. Langlands
motivation: For his visionary program connecting representation theory to number theory.

name: Peter D. Lax
motivation: For his groundbreaking contributions to the theory and application of partial differential equations and to the computation of their solutions.

name: Gregory Margulis
motivation: For providing innovative analysis of the structure of Lie groups. His work has had an impact on combinatorics, differential geometry, ergodic theory, dynamical systems, and Lie groups.

name: Yves Meyer
motivation: For his pivotal role in the development of the mathematical theory of wavelets.

name: John Willard Milnor
motivation: For proving that a 7-dimensional sphere can have several differential structures, which led to the creation of th e field of differential topology.

name: John F. Nash, Jr.
death_place: near Monroe Township, New Jersey, USA
motivation: Together with Louis Nirenberg, for striking and seminal contributions to the theory of nonlinear partial differential equations and its applications to geometric analysis.

name: Louis Nirenberg
motivation: Together with John F. Nash, Jr., for striking and seminal contributions to the theory of nonlinear partial differential equations and its applications to geometric analysis.

name: Jean-Pierre Serre
motivation: For achieving major results on the homotopy groups of spheres, especially through the use of the method of spectral sequences. He also reformulated and extended some of the main results of complex variable theory in terms of sheaves.

name: Yakov G. Sinai
motivation: For his fundamental contributions to dynamical systems, ergodic theory, and mathematical physics.

name: Isadore M. Singer
motivation: Together with Michael Francis Atiyah, for their discovery and proof of the index theorem, bringing together topology, geometry and analysis, and their outstanding role in building new bridges between mathematics and theoretical physics.

name: Endre Szemerédi
motivation: For his fundamental contributions to discrete mathematics and theoretical computer science, and in recognition of the profound and lasting impact of these contributions on additive number theory and ergodic theory.

name: John Torrence Tate
motivation: For his vast and lasting impact on the theory of numbers.

name: John Griggs Thompson
motivation: For proving, together with Walter Feit, that all non-cyclic finite simple groups have even order. The extension of this work by Thompson determined the minimal simple finite groups, i.e. the simple finite groups whose proper subgroups are solvable.

name: Jacques Tits
motivation: Together with John Griggs Thompson, for their profound achievements in algebra and in particular for shaping modern group theory.

name: Karen Keskulla Uhlenbeck
motivation: For her pioneering achievements in geometric partial differential equations, gauge theory and integrable systems, and for the fundamental impact of her work on analysis, geometry and mathematical physics.

name: Srinivasa S. R. Varadhan
motivation: For his fundamental contributions to probability theory and in particular for creating a unified theory of large deviations.

name: Sir Andrew John Wiles
motivation: For his stunning proof of Fermat’s Last Theorem by way of the modularity conjecture for semistable elliptic curves, opening a new era in number theory.
